security_audit.summary: Official Anthropic skill with no security concerns. The code performs local image processing using PIL, numpy, and imageio. No network access, no shell commands, no environment variable access, and no file system operations outside of reading and writing GIF files.

content.user_title: Create animated GIFs for Slack emoji and messages
content.value_statement: Creating GIFs that meet Slack requirements is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides validation tools and optimized builders to create perfect Slack GIFs every time.
actual_capabilities: Build GIFs with automatic color optimization and frame deduplication
Validate GIF dimensions and file size for Slack emoji requirements
Apply easing functions for smooth bounce, elastic, and back animations
Create gradient backgrounds and draw shapes like circles and stars
Resize and optimize GIFs specifically for 128x128 Slack emoji format
Calculate arc motion paths and squash-stretch effects for natural animation
limitations: Does not include pre-made graphics or emoji fonts
Requires PIL, numpy, and imageio libraries to be installed
Cannot render custom fonts reliably across platforms
Only creates GIFs from programmatically generated frames

use_cases.title: Create custom team emoji
use_cases.description: Build animated emoji for your Slack workspace that meet the 128x128 size requirement and display correctly.

use_cases.title: Automate GIF generation
use_cases.description: Use Python to programmatically create animated GIFs for documentation, tutorials, or feature demos.

use_cases.title: Optimize existing animations
use_cases.description: Reduce GIF file size while maintaining visual quality using color quantization and frame deduplication.

prompt_templates.title: Basic bouncing ball
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a bouncing ball GIF for Slack emoji. Make it 128x128 pixels with smooth bounce animation.

prompt_templates.title: Pulsing heart
prompt_templates.scenario: Create an animated emoji with effects
prompt_templates.prompt: Make a pulsing heart GIF for Slack. Use red color with a heartbeat rhythm that scales between 0.8 and 1.2 size.

prompt_templates.title: Spinning star
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a spinning gold star GIF for Slack emoji. Add elastic easing for a playful wobble effect at the end of each rotation.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-element scene
prompt_templates.prompt: Make a celebration GIF with confetti particles exploding outward from center. Use gradient background, apply gravity to particles, and fade them out over time.

output_examples.input: Create a bouncing ball GIF for Slack emoji
output: Optimized with 48 colors for Slack emoji
Ready to upload as custom Slack emoji

best_practices: Use 128x128 pixels and 48 colors or fewer for Slack emoji to ensure fast loading
Apply easing functions like bounce_out or elastic_out for natural motion
Keep animations under 3 seconds and 12 frames for optimal file size
anti_patterns: Do not use emoji fonts for graphics as they render differently across platforms
Do not create GIFs larger than 480x480 for Slack messages
Do not use more than 128 colors as it increases file size without visible quality gain

faq.question: What is the recommended size for Slack emoji GIFs?
faq.answer: 128x128 pixels is the recommended size. Slack will resize larger images, which can reduce quality.

faq.question: How can I reduce the file size of my GIF?
faq.answer: Use fewer frames, reduce colors to 48, enable remove_duplicates, and keep dimensions at 128x128.

faq.question: What easing functions are available?
faq.answer: Linear, ease_in, ease_out, ease_in_out, bounce_in, bounce_out, elastic_in, elastic_out, back_in, and back_out.

faq.question: Can I use uploaded images in my GIF?
faq.answer: Yes. Load images with PIL Image.open() and use them directly or as inspiration for colors and style.

faq.question: What dependencies do I need to install?
faq.answer: Install pillow, imageio, imageio-ffmpeg, and numpy using pip install.

faq.question: How do I validate if my GIF meets Slack requirements?
faq.answer: Use validate_gif() or is_slack_ready() from core.validators to check dimensions and get feedback.
